THE JOHNS-HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 24, 1930

DETECTIVES INVESTIGATE MYSTERIOUS
COTILLION CLUB
TO ELECT JUNIOR
The Cotillion Club, due to
loss of one of its members,
wishes to have its membership
completed again. All Juniors
who are interested in this activity are asked to attend the
meeting of the club on Wednesday, February 5 at 12.30
in library of Levering Hall.
These Juniors will then be
voted on and one will be elected to fill this vacancy.

CHANGES TAKING PLACE ON CAMPUS

ZEUCH TO SPEAK
AT LIBERAL LUNCHEON
President Zeuch of the
Commonwealth College of
Argansas, will address the
Liberal Club luncheon this
afternoon. The price of the
luncheon is fifty cents, everyone being invited to attend.
Anyone wishing to do so
will please notify Miss Roberts Wahl in the Psychology
Laboratory. The affair will be
held in Levering Hall at
12.30. This forms one of a
series of weekly lectures
given by the Liberal Club.

EDITORIALS
COMPLAINTS
performs two functions

editor-in-chief of the NEWS-LETTER
TbyHEmeans
of this column. First, he expounds on ideas concerning
by others,
Hopkins which are either his own or, having been suggested
seem to him worthy of comment. Secondly, he should endeavor to
express the opinions of the student body, whether or no he believes
those opinions to be well founded. A number of complaints have
come to this department in the last few weeks and, since they are
common to a number of undergraduates, they should be set forth.
Some we do not agree with, others 'seem just, but they all, at least,
should be presented to the student body.

THE CAFETERIA: By far the largest number of complaints have
to deal with the cafeteria in Levering Hall. "The prices are too high,"
is the main subject of the lamentations. A minor note is struck by
some who claim that "The food is no good," while a third group
mutter that "The portions aren't big enough." The prices of Mr.
Adams, Ph.D., are loudly extolled and his departure for parts unknown lamented. To prove that they are not partisan, the declaimers
against the cafeteria assert that everything was perfect in Levering Hall
at the beginning of the year.
EXAMINATIONS: The grounds for complaint against exams vary
with almost every individual. Briefly they are as follows: Exams are
childish, have no place in a first-class university, and therefore should
be abolished entirely; three hours is too short for a test on four
months' work; three hours is too long to write steadily; the period
for examinations is too short time, as more time should be allowed
between each one; the period for examinations is too long and we
should get them over with as quickly as possible in order to have a
rest before returning to college; the usual exam has too many memory
questions contained in it; exams do not give enough memory questions
as the professor goes outside of his subject in demanding knowledge
not in the text book; and so on ad infinitum.
THE MARKING SYSTEM: Only three classes of complaints on
this score: 1. The present marking system is terrible. 2. The new
marking system is terrible. 3. Any marking system is terrible.
ATHLETICS: A great number of students feel that Hopkins should
endeavor to attract good prep-school athletes in order to build up a
fine football team. They feel that the advertising value of a strong
team justifies any means, however drastic. Others, who do not agree
with the value to be derived from proselyting, still complain of the
fact that a poor team is bad advertising and recommend the abolition
of the gridiron sport altogether. The poor condition of the tennis
courts and the absence of proper locker and shower accommodations
have given rise to many murmurings, though these are growing fewer
since the announcement that the Conditions would be improved.
THE NEW PLAN: Many undergraduates maintain that the overemphasis placed on th6 new plan .is causing the rapid degeneration of
the undergraduate school. Some few complaints are being made against
the plan itself on the grounds that the men admitted to advance work
in the graduate school arc unprepared and also that the problems that
they interest themselves in have little or no value.
Well, there is, at least, plenty of room for discussion on the topics
listed above. Perhaps some solutions to the complaints may arise from
"bull-sessions," ostensibly called to study for exams: And, by the
way, good luck on the mid-years!

"GROM a mass of claims and counter." claims, one fact stands out--AMOCOGAS gives more miles per gallon—least
cost per mile.
This is proved every day by hundreds of
truck-fleet operators who must know to a
penny their .cost per mile--and by thousands of motorists who want low operating costs and better performance, too.
Prove it to yourself by figuring your own
cost per mile. Note how many more miles
you get to each gallon--how this extra
mileage cuts down your cost per mile.

THE JOHNS-HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 24, 1930

DETECTIVES INVESTIGATE MYSTERIOUS
COTILLION CLUB
TO ELECT JUNIOR
The Cotillion Club, due to
loss of one of its members,
wishes to have its membership
completed again. All Juniors
who are interested in this activity are asked to attend the
meeting of the club on Wednesday, February 5 at 12.30
in library of Levering Hall.
These Juniors will then be
voted on and one will be elected to fill this vacancy.

CHANGES TAKING PLACE ON CAMPUS

ZEUCH TO SPEAK
AT LIBERAL LUNCHEON
President Zeuch of the
Commonwealth College of
Argansas, will address the
Liberal Club luncheon this
afternoon. The price of the
luncheon is fifty cents, everyone being invited to attend.
Anyone wishing to do so
will please notify Miss Roberts Wahl in the Psychology
Laboratory. The affair will be
held in Levering Hall at
12.30. This forms one of a
series of weekly lectures
given by the Liberal Club.

EDITORIALS
COMPLAINTS
performs two functions

editor-in-chief of the NEWS-LETTER
TbyHEmeans
of this column. First, he expounds on ideas concerning
by others,
Hopkins which are either his own or, having been suggested
seem to him worthy of comment. Secondly, he should endeavor to
express the opinions of the student body, whether or no he believes
those opinions to be well founded. A number of complaints have
come to this department in the last few weeks and, since they are
common to a number of undergraduates, they should be set forth.
Some we do not agree with, others 'seem just, but they all, at least,
should be presented to the student body.

THE CAFETERIA: By far the largest number of complaints have
to deal with the cafeteria in Levering Hall. "The prices are too high,"
is the main subject of the lamentations. A minor note is struck by
some who claim that "The food is no good," while a third group
mutter that "The portions aren't big enough." The prices of Mr.
Adams, Ph.D., are loudly extolled and his departure for parts unknown lamented. To prove that they are not partisan, the declaimers
against the cafeteria assert that everything was perfect in Levering Hall
at the beginning of the year.
EXAMINATIONS: The grounds for complaint against exams vary
with almost every individual. Briefly they are as follows: Exams are
childish, have no place in a first-class university, and therefore should
be abolished entirely; three hours is too short for a test on four
months' work; three hours is too long to write steadily; the period
for examinations is too short time, as more time should be allowed
between each one; the period for examinations is too long and we
should get them over with as quickly as possible in order to have a
rest before returning to college; the usual exam has too many memory
questions contained in it; exams do not give enough memory questions
as the professor goes outside of his subject in demanding knowledge
not in the text book; and so on ad infinitum.
THE MARKING SYSTEM: Only three classes of complaints on
this score: 1. The present marking system is terrible. 2. The new
marking system is terrible. 3. Any marking system is terrible.
ATHLETICS: A great number of students feel that Hopkins should
endeavor to attract good prep-school athletes in order to build up a
fine football team. They feel that the advertising value of a strong
team justifies any means, however drastic. Others, who do not agree
with the value to be derived from proselyting, still complain of the
fact that a poor team is bad advertising and recommend the abolition
of the gridiron sport altogether. The poor condition of the tennis
courts and the absence of proper locker and shower accommodations
have given rise to many murmurings, though these are growing fewer
since the announcement that the Conditions would be improved.
THE NEW PLAN: Many undergraduates maintain that the overemphasis placed on th6 new plan .is causing the rapid degeneration of
the undergraduate school. Some few complaints are being made against
the plan itself on the grounds that the men admitted to advance work
in the graduate school arc unprepared and also that the problems that
they interest themselves in have little or no value.
Well, there is, at least, plenty of room for discussion on the topics
listed above. Perhaps some solutions to the complaints may arise from
"bull-sessions," ostensibly called to study for exams: And, by the
way, good luck on the mid-years!
